Award.AwardTitle: Chemistry Graduate Scholarship Program (GRASP) at Fresno State

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The S-STEM project is providing two-year integrated scholarships and support programs for five new graduate students each year who are seeking a M.S. degree in chemistry at California State University-Fresno (CSU-Fresno). This program is providing a diverse pool of students entering Ph.D. chemistry programs and M.S. level chemistry-based employment in Central California. The project is supplementing existing M.S. chemistry program elements at CSU-Fresno by providing additional opportunities for students to develop critical thinking, presentation and writing skills, and by preparing students for entry into graduate programs and the workforce. Because CSU-Fresno is a Hispanic Serving Institution, a large proportion of the targeted students are Hispanic, a critically under-represented group in STEM fields. These students are also serving as role models for minority undergraduate students in chemistry, helping to cultivate the next generation of graduate students. Assessment data from the project are being used to identify strategies that will promote the recruitment and retention of under-represented students into graduate programs that can be employed at similar institutions nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the project was to broaden the pool of students obtaining M.S. Chemistry degrees, and entering Ph.D Chemistry programs and Chemistry-based employment in Central California. The project provided scholarships to graduate students while also enhancing existing M.S. Chemistry program elements by providing additional opportunities to develop critical thinking, presentation and writing skills, and by preparing students for entry into Ph.D programs and the workforce.

 

A total of 28 students were supported during the project. The retention rate among students in the program was 93%, compared to 60% for non-supported students. All of the graduated students were co-authors on at least one regional or national conference presentation. Fourteen students have co-authored one or more peer-reviewed journal articles, ten of which have graduated (63% of graduates). Of the students that graduated, 19% are teaching at the community college and/or 4-year college level, 44% are pursuing an additional graduate degree and 31% are employed in the chemical industry or a government laboratory.

 

The program has had positive impacts beyond the students directly supported by the grant. The percentage of minority students in the program almost trebled from 13.5% to 31%. Enrollment in the M.S. Chemistry program has increased from 16 in 2010 to 30 in Fall 2016. The average number of M.S. Chemistry recipients has increased from 3.4/year in 2006-7 to 2011-12 to 9/year over the last three academic years.

 

Evaluations of student seminars and papers using established rubrics indicate that students writing and presentation skills have improved during the project period. Students are also meeting the department’s graduate writing requirement (which has historically been a stumbling block for many of our students) earlier than in previous years. Many of the co-curricular activities that contributed to these improvements have been institutionalized and embedded into the curriculum. Our data indicate that this model of financial support and mentoring can have a major impact on student success in STEM graduate programs at other large, comprehensive institutions with diverse, non-traditional student bodies.
